name: Harae (Purification)
shortDescription: Ritual purification that removes kegare (impurity) and restores connection with kami
fullDescription: Harae (Á•ì) or harai is the Shinto practice of purification and ritual cleansing that removes kegare (ritual impurity) and restores one to a state of purity suitable for communion with kami. The prototype for all harae is Izanagi's purification after escaping from Yomi (the underworld)‚Äîhe washed himself in a river, and from the purification emerged the three noble kami: Amaterasu, Tsukuyomi, and Susanoo. This established water purification as fundamental to Shinto practice. Harae takes many forms: misogi (Ê∞¥Á¶ä, water purification through immersion or ablution), temizu (ÊâãÊ∞¥, hand and mouth washing at shrine entrances), oharae (Â§ßÁ•ì, great purification ceremonies held biannually), harae-gushi (Á•ì‰∏≤, ritual wand waving), and salt purification. Harae is performed before entering sacred spaces, after contact with death or illness, at life transitions, to begin new enterprises, and regularly to maintain spiritual cleanliness. The practice is both physical (water, salt) and verbal (norito prayers). Harae doesn't remove moral guilt but rather spiritual pollution that naturally accumulates through living. The concept emphasizes renewal and return to original purity rather than sin and redemption.

manifestations.usage: Harae is practiced through: temizu (ritual hand and mouth washing at shrine entrances), misogi (full-body water purification, often in rivers, waterfalls, or the sea), salt purification (scattering salt to cleanse spaces or people), harae-gushi (priests waving paper-decorated wands), oharae ceremonies (great purifications on June 30 and December 31), recitation of purification prayers (norito), and passing through purification gates (chinowa kuguri, walking through sacred hoops).

linguistic.etymology: From Old Japanese 'hara-u' (to purify, to cleanse). The character Á•ì combines Á§∫ (altar/deity) + ÁäÆ (to strike/remove), literally meaning 'to remove impurity from the divine presence.' Classical Japanese continued this usage in Shinto liturgy.

originPoint.name: Japanese archipelago (universal practice)
originPoint.description: Harae purification practices originated across ancient Japan. The prototype purification was Izanagi's misogi at Tachibana-no-Odo in Himuka (modern Kyushu region).

firstAttestation.description: First written attestation in the Kojiki, describing Izanagi's purification after escaping Yomi.

timelinePosition.description: Harae purification practices likely emerged during the Yayoi period (300 BCE-300 CE) with animistic Shinto beliefs, codified during Kofun (300-538 CE) and Asuka periods (538-710 CE), continuing to present day.
